Literature Review: The Cox model, introduced by Sir David Cox in 1972, has had a profound impact on the analysis of censored survival data, with far-reaching implications in various disciplines. This seminal paper has stimulated extensive research in diverse areas, leading to significant theoretical and practical advances. The Cox model's influence can be seen in the development of semiparametric models, nonparametric efficiency, and partial likelihood methods. These extensions have enabled the estimation of covariate effects in complex data structures, where the central idea of sampling from the set of individuals at risk at time t remains a cornerstone. In this review, we will delve into the evolution of the Cox model, its extensions to competing risks, and the analysis of recurrent events, including the use of martingales and complete intensity models. We will also discuss the relative merits and domains of application of these models, highlighting their practical applications in various fields.
